To determine if there is legal ambiguity in the application of the statute to the fact pattern, we need to analyze whether the actions of the police officer described in the fact pattern constitute torture, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment as prohibited by Article 3. 

The statute prohibits torture or inhuman or degrading treatment. Torture is generally understood to involve severe pain or suffering, whether physical or mental, inflicted intentionally for purposes such as obtaining information, punishment, intimidation, or discrimination. Inhuman treatment refers to acts that cause serious mental or physical suffering, while degrading treatment covers treatment that humiliates or debases an individual.

In this case, the actions of the police officer include threatening the applicant, grabbing him, violently pushing him against a wall, and punching his ear, resulting in a traumatic rupture of the eardrum. The medical report described the health damage as "insignificant." The applicant argued that these actions amounted to inhuman and degrading treatment.

The ambiguity arises in determining whether the actions described, which resulted in physical harm and mental suffering to the applicant, meet the threshold of inhuman or degrading treatment as per Article 3. Therefore, to determine if there is legal ambiguity, one would need to assess the severity and impact of the actions in relation to the definitions of torture, inhuman, and degrading treatment provided under Article 3.
